title: 108_hr3616
content: The "Commission on Preemptive Foreign Policy and Military Planning Act" establishes a commission tasked with preemptive foreign policy and military planning duties. The Commission will review the doctrine of preemption in the National Security Strategy of the United States and assess its consequences for foreign policy and military planning. It will analyze the impact on foreign policy in key world theaters and relations between the US and nations in those regions. The Commission will assess the United States' commitments to allies, efforts in the war on terrorism, deployment capabilities, readiness, recruiting and retention rates, morale, force structure, and deployability of forces in various crisis scenarios. The Commission will evaluate the defense manufacturing base in the United States to support military needs, including potential supply deficiencies and increased demand from disagreements with foreign governments. The Commission will evaluate the defense manufacturing base in the United States, including potential supply deficiencies and increased demand from disagreements with foreign governments. Additionally, it will assess the accounting and budgeting structure of the Department of Defense and its ability to track, report, and project operating costs. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with expertise in relevant matters, serving for the Commission's duration. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Chair will be designated by the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Commission members will be appointed within 3 months of the Act's enactment. They will receive appropriate security clearances and be paid at a specified rate. Members of the Commission will be paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty. Full-time federal employees on the Commission cannot receive additional pay. Travel on military vehicles is allowed when necessary, and members will receive travel expenses. The Commission members will receive travel expenses and per diem for travel. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and meetings must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Commission members will receive travel expenses and per diem for travel. Meetings will be held upon the call of the Chair after all members have been appointed. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chair, paid at a rate not exceeding GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Chair may appoint up to 3 staff members with pay not exceeding GS-15. The Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Chair of the Commission can request personnel from Federal agencies to assist without reimbursement in carrying out duties under this Act. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Chair of the Commission can request personnel from Federal agencies to assist without reimbursement in carrying out duties under this Act. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. They can obtain official data from US agencies and use the US mails. Administrative support services can be requested. They can obtain official data from US agencies and use the US mails. The Administrator of General Services shall provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 6 months of its first meeting, detailing findings, conclusions, recommendations, and budgetary implications of a preemptive foreign policy. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report, and necessary funds are authorized for the Act's implementation.
